summary: RESEÑA: ¡CAPITAN MARVEL, UN VIAJE A LOS 90’S! #shironodesaina #nekodemonio #CorporativoArcanos #Noticias #Marvel #Cine #Reseña
title: RESEÑA: ¡CAPITAN MARVEL, UN VIAJE A LOS 90’S! #shironodesaina #nekodemonio #CorporativoArcanos #Noticias #Marvel #Cine #Reseña
body:
RESEÑA: ¡CAPITAN MARVEL, UN VIAJE A LOS 90’S! #shironodesaina #nekodemonio #CorporativoArcanos #Noticias #Marvel #Cine #Reseña

La semana pasada llegó a cines la más reciente entrega del Universo Marvel. Capitan Marvel, en esta historia de origen, con una historia sencilla, pero bastante entretenida que sirve de pretexto para introducir a este nuevo personaje, como lo fueron Doctor Strange o Ant Man.

Marvel tenía la complicada tarea de introducir a un personaje que sólo Nick Fury conoce, que es de los super héroes más…

View On WordPress

External image

La semana pasada llegó a cines la más reciente entrega del Universo Marvel. Capitan Marvel, en esta historia de origen, con una historia sencilla, pero bastante entretenida que sirve de pretexto para introducir a este nuevo personaje, como lo fueron Doctor Strange o Ant Man.

Marvel tenía la complicada tarea de introducir a un personaje que sólo Nick Fury conoce, que es de los super héroes más…

summary: By the way, I saw Captain Marvel today. It was pretty good, but really I think Carol’s best friend, Maria, would have made a...
body: By the way, I saw Captain Marvel today. It was pretty good, but really I think Carol’s best friend, Maria, would have made a better lead. The actress’ performance was much better. i looked it up as I knew there was a Captain Marvel before Carol, other than Mar-vell. Apparently her name is Monica Rambeau, who in the movie is Maria’s daughter. But it wouldn’t take much changing at all for Maria to have become what Carol was, simply have her take the place in that plane. I would like to have seen that movie, really.

The actress’ performance was much better. i looked it up as I knew there was a Captain Marvel before Carol, other than Mar-vell. Apparently her name is Monica Rambeau, who in the movie is Maria’s daughter. But it wouldn’t take much changing at all for Maria to have become what Carol was, simply have her take the place in that plane. I would like to have seen that movie, really.

Apparently her name is Monica Rambeau, who in the movie is Maria’s daughter. But it wouldn’t take much changing at all for Maria to have become what Carol was, simply have her take the place in that plane. I would like to have seen that movie, really.
trail.content: By the way, I saw Captain Marvel today. It was pretty good, but really I think Carol’s best friend, Maria, would have made a better lead. The actress’ performance was much better. i looked it up as I knew there was a Captain Marvel before Carol, other than Mar-vell. Apparently her name is Monica Rambeau, who in the movie is Maria’s daughter. But it wouldn’t take much changing at all for Maria to have become what Carol was, simply have her take the place in that plane. I would like to have seen that movie, really.

summary:
Haven't seen Captain Marvel yet, planning on it soon. 
The chief complaint I heard was the idea that the movie is "pushing...
body:
Haven’t seen Captain Marvel yet, planning on it soon.

The chief complaint I heard was the idea that the movie is “pushing feminism”, but Carol Denvers has always just been that way as a character.

blog.name: corvidaezero
blog.title: i run on energy drinks and feminism

tags: it's the amazon photos all over again
summary: There is a difference between supporting a real life woman who wants to wear make-up or dress sexy -- because women should be...
body:
There is a difference between supporting a real life woman who wants to wear make-up or dress sexy – because women should be able to dress and wear whatever they want, etc – versus fictional women written by men doing those things.

Because the second example isn’t “let women wear what they want”.  Fictional characters are completely controlled by whoever is writing/directing them.  Harley Quinn dressing the way she does in Suicide Squad isn’t “letting women wear what they want”.  Harley Quinn is a fictional character – she can’t actually make choices?  It’s the guy who wrote and directed Suicide Squad who decided to dress her up like that, not Harley.

So when we’re saying that we don’t like that the new Avengers: Endgame trailer has Carol in a face full of dolled-up make-up, we aren’t saying that Brie Larson, as a real human woman, in her own free time, can’t wear that.  Go for it, bb.  What we’re saying is that the men who wrote and directed the new Avengers movie told her she needed to wear it.  And those are two extremely different things.

(Especially considering the juxtaposition of her appearance when Carol was written/directed by a woman.)

You can’t necessarily apply real world feminism to fictional worlds, especially those owned/created/written by men.  You have to use a meta-feminism, as it were.  Carol isn’t wearing make-up because she wants to and fuck the patriarchy – she’s wearing make-up because Joe and Anthony Russo thought she looked good with a smile.

reblog.comment:

trail.content:
There is a difference between supporting a real life woman who wants to wear make-up or dress sexy – because women should be able to dress and wear whatever they want, etc – versus fictional women written by men doing those things.

Because the second example isn’t “let women wear what they want”.  Fictional characters are completely controlled by whoever is writing/directing them.  Harley Quinn dressing the way she does in Suicide Squad isn’t “letting women wear what they want”.  Harley Quinn is a fictional character – she can’t actually make choices?  It’s the guy who wrote and directed Suicide Squad who decided to dress her up like that, not Harley.

So when we’re saying that we don’t like that the new Avengers: Endgame trailer has Carol in a face full of dolled-up make-up, we aren’t saying that Brie Larson, as a real human woman, in her own free time, can’t wear that.  Go for it, bb.  What we’re saying is that the men who wrote and directed the new Avengers movie told her she needed to wear it.  And those are two extremely different things.

summary: 74 Years of Captain America: A History of Marvel’s America-iest Superhero
body:
So,, I saw a comment on a post saying that all politically motivated art is shit.

And I just don’t understand what people think art even is.

Art does not exist in a bubble. Because artists don’t live in bubbles. Like it or not, the culture surrounding an artist influences the work they create. Including political culture.

When analyzing artworks, there’s lenses called artist context and historical context (among others). Both of these are extremely relevant especially when looking at comic books as a form of art.

For an example, here’s an excerpt from an article about the history of Captain America.

“And given that Captain America was created in the early 40s (his premiere issue went on sale December 20, 1940), his ultra-patriotic nature had a purpose. Simon and Kirby were not what you would call “fans” of Nazi Germany’s blitzkriegs throughout Europe. But the USA still wouldn’t join the war effort in 1940, and so Simon and Kirby needed a hero who could embody the American intervention they believed was right.

Which is why the cover of “Captain America #1” was Steve Rogers punching Hitler in the face. And why “Captain America #2” was Steve Rogers about to punch Hitler in the face. Granted, not every early Cap book had its eponymous hero in some stage of Fuhrer-assaulting, but pounding on Nazis was a common occurrence in Cap’s early days (and after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, Cap graciously included Emperor Hirohito in his campaign of “Punching Everyone We Fought in WWII”).” (Link below)

So ANYWAY.

I’m not necessarily writing this in defense of either political side, because there’s political influenced work on both ends of the spectrum. I’m writing this more to remind everyone that there has never been a point in time where art hasn’t been politically influenced. If I had more time on my hands, I would make this into a whole essay going all the way back to the gdamn Renaissance and talk about how politically loaded that art used to be, but nah.

Moral of the story: think critically about the media you consume, and try to remove your own personal biases. Don’t pretend something isn’t political simply because it aligns with your views, and don’t call something else out *only* because it’s a different view. Every form of art in every form of media has layers and deeper messages.

Thanks for coming to my ted talk

(I used Captain America for this because he’s such a blatantly political figure, but despite this he’s extremely popular, and his films are some of the most well received of the recent chain of superhero movies.)

74 Years of Captain America: A History of Marvel’s America-iest Superhero

blog.name: daphnie1
blog.description:
"Iron Man." That's kind of catchy. It's got a nice ring to it. 

Hi and welcome to my blog. I mainly reblog/post Marvel, both comics and MCU, Star Trek and some Sherlock and Doctor Who. My ship tags are otp:spacehusbands (Kirk/Spock) and otp:at least you've got me watching over you (Tony/Steve).

blog.name: justarandomgreenie
blog.title: Let's get one thing straight, I'm not
blog.description: Congrats, you found my messy blog // Sarcasm is my first language // I'm a Hufflepuff, and if you call Badgers anything else than badass, I will stab you // If you mess with @therunningspiderman u mess with me// oh and also please go follow my rp blog @gred-and-forge-weasleyy // that's it I guess //

blog.name: bramblepatch
blog.title: Words Mean Things
blog.description:
Shannon, but you can call me Bramble. 28. They/them pronouns. Sometimes I get the morbs. Assorted fandoms. Lots of complaining about things I like. Strange ideas of what constitutes a cute animal.

Probably not actually a quagsire IRL. Avatar by tumblr user gamzee.

summary: Nicholas J Fury spent one weekend in the 90s hanging out with a cool lesbian and then spent the next twenty years trying and...
body: Nicholas J Fury spent one weekend in the 90s hanging out with a cool lesbian and then spent the next twenty years trying and failing to find another superhero with her general degree of competence or emotional maturity
